Why the test target is changed from "_create_network()" to "network()"? From the upstream code, _create_network() seems to simulate the network creation API call.
both of them simulates the network creation, other tests use network() more often than _create_network(), suspicion here is that _create_network is causing some issues because of mock.
I assume the reason you made a change was to fix some issue. However, it seemed that you haven't root caused the issue yet, but rather find a workaround.

You are right on this. I am confident that the fix I proposed  here is fine and satisfies the intention of the tests. But the reasons that why the original tests failed on upstream tests are not clear (Tough I do have some suspicion). There doesn't seem to be any recent changes that would contribute to the errors. Other vendors' plugin do different set of tests, and the tests might also be different. (And some other plugins have not been updated for quite some time.) One thing I could do is to add few debug logs to other branches and force them to fail, so that the error logs can be printed. I could do more investigation if the effort is considered worth.

This is UT that we added, we are just reusing upstream's existing functions to achieve our goal. We are not testing _create_network. What we are trying to test is "rollback on network create". As long as the function that we use can achieve the goal, it shouldn't matter which we choose to use. self.network() is used much more often in our other tests, right now I have no clue why _create_network was used specifically for this test, and not other tests. One thing I noticed was that, self.network seems to configure context which _create_network does not, it might be the reason why it failed the original test.
The original unit test is to verify the rollback for _create_network(). You can write a new unit test to test rollback for network(), but can't change the test target here.
Not sure why copy the same code here and mock the parent. The test now doesn't serve any purpose. If it is the intent, just "pass".
If this test is no different from the upstream test, why over-write it?
We just merged recently and didn't see an issue. Needs to add some logs to other branches and force the test to fail to get more information.
The original test was mocking it, our plugin codes inherited from the plugin and our test is supposed to test the same thing.
The original test was not mocking the right method. It mocked NeutronRestProxyV2Base, instead of NeutronRestProxyV2. Looking at upstream codes, the intent is to mock the actual plugin method.
If it is the case, then other branches have the same issue?

This is a new test case, not defined by the upstream. The unit test is not testing  _create_network API.

the rollback testing was not part of the the upstream, but if we added it for the plugin we should test it for ml2 driver. Basically there are two sets of UT, one is for db/plugin, the other is for ml2 driver.

self.network uses _create_network to create the network.

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/tests/unit/db/test_db_base_plugin_v2.py#L670

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/tests/unit/db/test_db_base_plugin_v2.py#L503

I am also a bit confused why we need to test them twice. Currently the understanding is that we are following upstream design. The ML2 driver was introduced some time after the initial plugin design, so they were testing a bit different things, some tests that are successful for the driver fails for the plugin, while sometimes the opposite is true. Here we are mostly trying to ensure the upstream driver tests are covered here, in addition to some ones that we feel needed.
Though I don't know why we added the rollback test, but if we added it for the plugin, it's reasonable that we also test for the driver.

Based on some testing, using _create_network will actually pass the test here. But I want it to be consistent so I changed to self.network(). (Other UT here uses self.network() instead of _create_network, and the underscore also implies that we probably should not use it.)

I understand there are two sets of UTs. ML2 driver calls our plugin. What extra test is this UT covered that plugin UT doesn't? And same comment as previous one, the test target is _create_network, not network().

Hi Jose,
ok so basically I think the problem here is different: the delegation is now correct and we're not on the undercloud anymore, so we can see the right node ("controller-0"), but the next task which sets the "container_cli" fact still uses hostvars[inventory_hostname]: this points to the undercloud facts (the source host of the playbook) and that's the reason we're still seeing "podman" instead of "docker".
This is wrong and should be set on the delegated host. For standalone deployments, or for scenarios different from upgrades, we can still fallback on the inventory_hostname.

So after some testing we figured out the `container_cli` fact is only present at tht level and in the upgrade scenario is always set to "podman" because tht moved the value to podman since Rocky.
For this reason if the undercloud is update (train) but the overcloud is still waiting for the upgrade process (queens), this value should be computed by executing a query on the overcloud controller (ceph_mon|first).

we set podman by default, but we can meet the requirements for the upgrade process with an if statement which depends on the previous task and it's executed only when the docker sock if found on the controller.
I may be wrong - but I have a vague memory of delegation with omit not working.

Yeah, you're right, tripleo_delegate_to is treated as a variable here, so this task will fail if it's not defined, and omit can be actually avoided.
This task has `ignore_errors: true`, this means if it fails looking for a monitor the next block is skipped.
Of course the tripleo_delegate_to undefined is one of the causes this task can fail, so we're still covered if the variable is not passed or it's wrong.

I'm wondering if by setting a fact with the very same name as container_cli, you are not overriding the container_cli fact for the whole deployment. As if that's the case, you might be breaking the deployment tasks which could come after. As we are using this fact only in this validation, can't we use a different name to avoid conflicts?

The THT output generates group_vars, doesn't it? Although in some locations it sets other things. If anyone has a generated set to look at, then it can be mapped against https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_variables.html#variable-precedence-where-should-i-put-a-variable to figure out the precedence.

That said, using a different var name guarantees that everything is OK.

Yeah, the goal is to make this validation use the container_cli variable computed according to what is installed on the overcloud, and not relying anymore on the tht variable which cannot cover all the use cases.
For this reason the best way to do that is to change the variable name: this is more robust and less error-prone for validation purposes.

This is a good point. TBH I'm not sure if this fact exists only in this scope or it's used in the next deployments (since it's cached somewhere).
The best thing we can do is change the variable name and avoid aliasing.
In the validation we shouldn't rely on the tht defined variable, so we should compute and assign it according to the overcloud facts.

Francesco, Please add a when so we only set this fact if it's not set.

Jose, do you think that will address your concern?

Hey John, I don't think so.
container_cli is always defined at tht level, so this task will always find an already existing container_cli variable.
For this reason I think we should change the name of this variable in validation and don't rely on the original container_cli since it's global and cannot reflect the whole state of the cluster in all the use cases.
We will always have podman as default, looking for docker when the socket exist in the ceph_mon groups.

Agree with Francesco, if we include the conditional then his latest changes won't work for FFWD. As it will take the value defined from tht (which will point to podman independently that all overcloud nodes are still on Queens, so using docker) and the validation will fail.

John,
this can avoid aliasing with container_cli, which can break the upgrades use cases because it's a static values and doesn't change in function of the state of the cluster or the use case.
As you can see in defaults/main.yaml has still "podman" as default value, or you can ovverride the value running something like:

ansible-playbook -i tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml ceph-health.yaml -e "container_client=myclient"

but this should avoid aliasing with container_cli variable and avoid us breaking the next phases just because we're adding extra logic here.

I retested (both w/o and with Ceph), including running a:
sysinv-helm create-armada-app-overrides ./ stx-monitor

Have a nice weekend.

deployment/keystone/keystone-container-p.message:
As I mentioned earlier too, __this assumes__ that memcached service is available wherever keystone is deployed. 

Probably not true right? We probably have to ensure that some way if we go with this assumption.

I understood your point but I believe there doesn't exist such kind of dependency validation TripleO now.
For example operators can disable swift by Set None for all swift resources, glance tries to swift as its backend unless they explicitly change its backend.
So IMO operators should update template parameters "correctly" according to their deployment pattern if they want to change deployed resources.

If deployment without memcached is actually required, how about adding an example template, which disables memcached and sets required parameters to disable memcached usage ?
I initially thought to implement some parameters to configure caching, but I removed all parameters after getting feedback in heat cache patch[1]
However we might be able to set a simple parameter to disable usage of memcache and can set these parameters in that example template.

 [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/716967/

It is correct this assumes that memcached service is available in the same deployment.
However this doesn't require memcached run on the same node as keystone, because memcached_ips should be set according to the node where memcached is actually running.

I agree that we can implement a validation to make sure that memcached is enabled and available in the same deployment. However there are several implementation like nova cache[1] or authtoken cache which already assumes that memcached should be available in the deployment without any actual validations, and honestly I doubt the profit of strict validation only in keystone caching.

 [1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/base/nova.pp#L132-L136

In addition, memcached service is enabled by default, and I don't expect that operators tries to disable memcached for any reason.

Should this be done conditionally if they do attempt to disable memcached?

With this approach, if an operator disables memcached the keystone configuration is still going to try and connect to something.

You can probably verify this in the logs if you set debug_cache_backend = True and bump the log level for oslo.cache to DEBUG.

Keystone, and oslo.cache, currently don't fail if they can't connect to a defined caching server. You'd see it attempt to pull things out of the cache only to always log a MISS.

I'm wondering if that's going to be confusing for users if they see caching configured (because it's not done conditionally) but there isn't a co-located memcached instance and keystone won't bark at you if it can't connect to it.

doc/source/admin/drivers/idrac.rst.message:
need to clarify - it causes `clean failed` even if there are no further clean steps.

It is expected that even if there is only factory_reset step, then in the end node is in `manageable` state. Currently, if using non-default PXE interface, then after reset Ironic is not able to communicate that factory reset was successful and after timeout it enters `clean failed` state. (Although factory reset actually succeeded).

It's correct that if there are more steps after `factory_reset`, then it fails as well, this time it's kinda correct to say that clean failed because other steps couldn't be executed, but it's still not smth that user expects.

thanks for the updates.

I did test with R740dx with single factory_reset step and it still timed out. So I would not complicate the things and just drop the "if there are more more clean steps after this" condition.

From my testing the conditions for failure are 1) UEFI boot mode 2) non-standard pxe interface.

However, I found R740dx server iwth configuration that succeeded and the reason is that it didn't meet point 2), its PXE was configured to 1-1-1 and reset didn't change that as it is the same as default.

Moreover, today I also noticed another thing, both on R640 and R740dx - the clean succeeded, but when looking at the changes, they are actually not there. This might be another thing, I need to look into. After retrying cleaning, the changes are applied and based on pxe configuration it failed or succeeded.

So maybe you can doublecheck if your R740dx has non-default pxe interface or if after the factory reset the settings are actually reset.
For the record, this was tested with R640, iDRAC 4.00.00.00, BIOS 2.4.8

This should be:

    any2array($backend_name).each |String $backend| {

The unit tests were failing because puppet was iterating over each character in 'tripleo_dellemc_sc'. This would have led to *many* backends, but it halted when it hit the second 'e' because that caused a duplicate backend, also named 'e'.

This occurred because the default hiera lookup at L35 is a string. Compare this to [1], but note the array brackets around 'tripleo_pure'. But adding brackets to the L35 default value is NOT the correct solution. Instead, use any2array as suggested above. Btw, I've made a note to submit a patch to fix the Pure backend (use any2array instead of brackets).

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/src/branch/master/manifests/profile/base/cinder/volume/pure.pp#L35

-1: this needs to be any2array($backend_name).each ...

This prevents the code from iterating over a string in the event the hiera lookup on L35 returns a string. The default hiera value is an array, but what if the actual hiera value is a string?

Yep, totally wild and unrealistic. It's a way to force specifically-crafted instances to land in specific places, so that we can assert stuff about which CPUs are pinned in a 100% deterministic way. In my whitebox integration tests I can just change vcpu_pin_set per compute, but in func tests CONF is global for all computes. I can't think of a way of achieving the same thing when using realistic NUMA topologies. For instance, 2 hosts with 2 NUMA cells each, 4 CPUs per cell. Boot an instance with 4 CPUs. Where does it land? No idea. Live migrate it. Where does it go? No idea. With these 2-cell and 2/3-cell hosts, a 3-CPU instance can *only* go in the 3-cell, which leaves the 2-CPU instance to move around between the 2 2-cells, and because the first 2-cell is [0, 1] and the second [3, 4], it gives us meaningful assertions to make about which CPUs are pinned at what time.

We could use decorator and wrap this class, but I think utilizing 'metaclass' is the least horrible approach here. Feel free to ping me for pointers on this if needed.

I disagree that singleton are non-pythonic.
The main issue we've with singleton is it isn't thread safe which is handled in the code with the help of threading lock and conditional.
But we don't wait, we raise in this case? If we are supposed to wait here, shouldn't we have wait logic with some reasonable timeout instead of failing right away?

There are 2 cases here:
1) the wait is done with the help of self.cond that won't allow state initialization until other thread has completed
2) The exception is raised when we fail to intialize the MountState class
Why the try here? What are we expecting to fail?

Here we get the mount state and perform the desired mount/umount operation.
If anything occurs during the whole process, we atleast free up the thread in the finally block so other threads can do their operations.
I think the point of this code is to make it work as a generator so i would prefer to keep it this way.

Very trivial nit, but should all be on a single line, else it should be a summary line separated from a longer description.

But I'm probably the only one that has a fixation with pep257. :)

glance_store/common/fs_mount.py.message: NIT: two empty lines here to separate the LOG from imports
Would be good to have at least one blank line after the last import.

As discussed around on IRC we probably should walk through the mount path and see if we have any mounts lingering upon startup and clean those. that would avoid us leaking mounts/sockets over restarts.

Not sure if it belongs here or in the _HostMountState
I don't see this implemented anywhere.
Yep, this was related to the vm's on the compute host and mountpoints associated with them, it isn't used/required in this case so removed.
Shouldn't need to force this into a string when it's being formatted into a string with %s.
Odd to have a one line comment broken into multiple, but I don't think you need to call out in the docstring what a method is being called by. That has potential to change over time anyway.

this should be inside if condition defined at line #94,

also provide appropriate comments wherever possible
This is line 94 so not sure what you are thinking of.
Should we log this as debug, as we are not failing/breaking execution here?
If exception occurs at line 106, then this line will throw error 'dirs' used before assignment

I think we should be able to replace all this L#103-112 with:

if os.path.isdir(mountpoint):
    dirs = os.listdir(mountpoint)
else:
    continue

instead of going through processutils and invoking shell and then doing string operation on top of that.

Also this return on line 112 stops our iteration and potentially leaves mountpoints unchecked.

Might want to do sanitization of only dirs on that list in case there is other files in the mount base.

Done
So there are 2 things here:
1) We don't recommend using the mount point directory for any personal file/directories
2) The rmdir will return NotADirectoryError for files so that will be logged but won't be deleted anyway so we're safe here
Ditto we could replace this with simple `os.rmdir(dir)`
This entire code block from line #85 to #126 needs to be arranged properly and should be commenting so that reviewer will get idea what exactly is happening here.

The lock is used when we delete records in the existing attachments in the memory to avoid races.
In this case, since there are no attachments, it will just log it and continue with the unmounting (if mounted)
Doesn't this L#126 fail when it hits L#213 and the mountpoint doesn't exists in the mountpoints that we were already tracking?
And this could be replaced with os.makedirs()
This shouldn't work/be needed as the os.listdir returns list, not a string.

NIT:
we don't required this as we have global HOST defined.
Just to note so that we can get rid of this in refactoring during V cycle

tripleoclient/utils.py.message: So i think this is wrong and we need to fix the spot where heat is used. Heat has a different verbosity level than ansible. This turns on ansible verbosity by default (which is a bit much)
Then we should not link osc verbose_level with ansible verbosity at all if we need translation. I mentioned about that (in a comment) when I proposed the patch

We need a way to enable verbosity. verbose_level comes from --debug --verbose etc on the cli params. If someone runs --debug we get a higher verbose_level and would turn on ansible debug with cli debug. This is the correct place to do it. it's just osclient has always had 1 by default for some reason rather than being 0 if no --verbose or --debug is provided (no idea the history on this). This is about the 3rd or 4th time i've had to address this exact thing.

apt_args.verbose_level is 1 by default. so we end up turning it on. The issue is the translation from osclient verbose level to something usable by everyone else. Ansible itself needs to not be verbose by default. We always want to print the heat stack events.

I don't see anything wrong with heatclient verbosity as we use the client verbosity > 0 to log the events.

Are we saying we'll use client verbosity(verbose_level) when it's > 1 (L240) as ansible verbosity, but override it to 0 when it's 1(default). This seems unintuitive to me.
